questions.text: What route of administration of the shocking dose of an antigen is most effective in causing an anaphylactic reaction?
questions.solution:
The intravenous route of administration is the most effective route of administration for shocking dose in causing anaphylaxis.

Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity syndrome. There are 2 clinical syndromes which are characterised as:

  • Anaphylaxis - acute, potentially fatal systemic form
  • Atopy - chronic, recurrent, non-fatal, localized form

Priming dose: For induction of hypersensitivity reactions, the host should have contact with the antigen, leading to priming of the appropriate B or T lymphocytes. 

Shocking dose: Subsequent contact with allergen causing manifestations of hypersensitivity.

Effectiveness: intravenous > intraperitoneally~subcutaneously > intradermally (least)

Related Pearl: Types of Hypersensitivity

Type of reaction Clinical Syndrome Time for manifestation Mediators
Type I:
IgE type

1. Anaphylaxis

2. Atopy

 Minutes IgE: histamine and other pharmacological agents
Type II:
Cytolytic, cytotoxic

Antibody-mediated damage: e.g. thrombocytopenia, agranulocytosis, hemolytic anemia

 Hours to days IgG, IgM
Type III:
Immune complex

1.Arthus-reaction

2.Serum-sickness

 Hours to days IgG, IgM, leucocytes
Type IV:
Delayed hypersensitivity

1. Tuberculin

2. Contact dermatitis

 Hours to days T cells, lymphokines, macrophages.

questions.text: Which type of reaction is the Schultz-Dale phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The Schultz–Dale phenomenon is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. 

It describes in-vitro contraction of smooth muscles that have been exposed to antigens, demonstrating immediate hypersensitivity reaction in some human and animal tissues.  

Other type I hypersensitivity reactions are the Prausnitz-Kustner reaction and the Theobald Smith phenomenon.

questions.text: The presence of which of the following antibodies is demonstrated by the Prausnitz-Kustner reaction?
questions.solution:
The presence and activity of IgE antibodies are demonstrated by the Prausnitz–Küstner (P–K) reaction.

In this method, the serum is injected from an allergic person into the skin of a nonallergic individual. Then a suspected antigen is later injected into the same site. A positive P-K reaction is a wheal and flare reaction seen in the non-allergic individual. This indicates that the suspected antigen is causing hypersensitivity. Because of the danger of transmitting viral hepatitis and AIDS, this test is no longer used.

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This child who developed tingling in the mouth, and swelling of the lips and face after eating shelf life is an example of an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and affects the whole body. It is characterized by a sudden release of histamines and other chemicals from the immune system in response to an allergen, such as certain foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. The onset of symptoms can occur within minutes to a few hours after exposure to the allergen.The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. 

Clinically, anaphylaxis can present with a combination of symptoms that typically include:

  • Respiratory Symptoms: Patients often experience wheezing and respiratory distress due to bronchoconstriction. Other signs may include shortness of breath, coughing, and a feeling of tightness in the chest.
  • Skin Symptoms: Urticaria (hives) and angioedema (swelling of the skin and mucous membranes) are common. These skin reactions usually develop rapidly, often within minutes to two hours of exposure to the allergen.
  • Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a key indicator of anaphylaxis. Patients may also experience tachycardia (increased heart rate) and, in severe cases, shock.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps can occur, particularly if the anaphylaxis is triggered by food allergens.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, or loss of consciousness can occur due to the sudden drop in blood pressure and reduced oxygen supply to the brain.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: Two days after penicillin administration, a patient developed antibodies that resulted in hemolysis. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Penicillin in high doses can result in immune-mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism. In this, the drug attaches to surface of RBC membrane. Antibodies are produced that are targeted against this combination of penicillin and RBCs. 

Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A skin transplant was done from a sister to her brother. After a few years, a brother-to-sister skin transplant was done, but rejection occurred. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes an Eichwald-Silmser effect, which is a unilateral sex-linked histo-incompatibility.

While transplants between same-sex siblings are successful, grafts from female to male are also successful, but an exception is seen when the donor is a male and the recipient is a female. Such grafts are rejected as the grafted male tissue (XY) will have antigens determined by the Y chromosome which will be absent in the female (XX) recipient.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought with complaints of sensitivity to light and profuse lacrimation. On inspection, the given finding is seen on her upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Spring catarrh or vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

It is a bilateral, seasonally recurrent, chronic conjunctivitis due to type I hypersensitivity allergic reaction to an external antigen. The antigen reacts with IgE, this stimulates mast cell degranulation leading to the release of histamine and other mediators of the allergic response.

Spring catarrh is one of the several forms of allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants?
questions.solution:
Hyperacute graft rejection is an example of type II hypersensitivity reaction.

It is mediated by preformed antibodies. It is a rare event that occurs in kidney transplantation.

Graft rejection Time taken for rejection Immune mechanisms involved Type of hypersensitivity
Hyperacute Minutes to hours Preformed antibodies II
Acute Weeks to months Cytotoxic T-cell mediated IV
Chronic  Months to years Chronic DTH mediated and Ab mediated IV

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

Related Pearl: Transplant Rejection and Hypersensitivity

Type of Rejection  Type of Hypersensitivity

Host vs Graft
Hyperacute Type 2
Acute Type 2 and 4
Chronic Type 2 and 4
Graft vs Host
Graft vs host reaction Type 4

 

The image given below explains the pathophysiology of hyperacute graft rejection (type II hypersensitivity). 

The image below shows the mechanism of type IV hypersensitivity in graft rejection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about anaphylaxis?

choices.text: It is a type I hypersensitivity reaction
Primary mediators like IL 4, IL 5 and GM-CSF are released

questions.solution:
IL4, IL5, GM-CSF are secondary mediators and not primary mediators.

Anaphylaxis is a type I reaction and is mediated through IgE.

Primary mediators are preformed contents of mast cells and basophil granules such as histamine, serotonin. They cause vasodilation and bronchoconstriction. Secondary mediators are newly formed upon stimulation by mast cells, basophils, and other leucocytes (such as leukotrienes IL3, IL4, IL5, IL6; GM-CSF, and prostaglandins) which lead to inflammatory cell infiltrates.

questions.text: While studying the patient data on hypersensitivity reactions over the last 2 months, you are tasked with classifying the cases by type. Who among the following patients falls under type II hypersensitivity?

choices.text: Eczematous reaction on the hand of an HCW wearing powdered gloves
A patient with heat intolerance, sinus tachycardia, and proptosis
Glomerulonephritis in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.solution:
Heat intolerance, sinus tachycardia, and proptosis of the eye suggest a diagnosis of Grave's disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that results in the binding of anti-thyroid-stimulating hormone (anti-TSH) antibodies to TSH receptors and stimulates the thyroid cells to produce thyroid hormones.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve combining the of IgG antibodies with the antigenic determinants on the surface of cells leading to cytotoxic effects.

Other options:

Option A: Berylliosis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Option B: Eczematous reaction on the hand of an HCW wearing powdered gloves (contact dermatitis) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Option D: Glomerulonephritis in a patient with SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old hiker presents with an itchy rash on her wrist. She gives a history of getting brushed with poison ivy on a trek the previous day. What cells are involved in this reaction?
questions.solution:
The history and image suggest a diagnosis of contact dermatitis, a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells. These are delayed hypersensitivity reactions and are induced by sensitized T cells, which on contact with the specific antigen releases cytokines that produce biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Two types of delayed hypersensitivity are:

  • Tuberculin type
  • Contact dermatitis type

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive man complains of fever, migraine, loss of appetite, and myalgia. On examination, splinter hemorrhages and palpable purpura are noted. On CT angiography, aneurysm and stenosis of medium-sized vessels are observed. What is the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. It is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  1. Formation of immune complexes
  2. Deposition of immune complexes
  3. Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions: 

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • SLE
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction
  • Farmer’s lung
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Type II lepra reaction
  • Henoch Schonlein purpura

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in the autoimmune disease shown below?
questions.solution:
The disease shown in the image is myasthenia gravis. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibodies directed towards self-antigens- cell surface or extracellular matrix. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient comes with recurrent episodes of sneezing, rhinorrhea, and watering of the eyes. She says she has these symptoms throughout the year. Which of the following immunoglobulins will be elevated in her case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of chronic allergic rhinits. IgE is elevated in these cases. 

Perennial allergic rhinitis, a type of chronic rhinitis is a year-round problem and is often caused by indoor allergens such as dust and animal dander in addition to pollens that may exist at the time. Symptoms tend to occur regardless of the time of the year.

Related Pearl: Types of Hypersensitivity

Type of reaction Clinical Syndrome Time for manifestation Mediators
Type I:
IgE type

1. Anaphylaxis

2. Atopy

 Minutes IgE: histamine and other pharmacological agents
Type II:
Cytolytic, cytotoxic

Antibody-mediated damage: e.g. thrombocytopenia, agranulocytosis, hemolytic anemia

 Hours to days IgG, IgM
Type III:
Immune complex

1.Arthus-reaction

2.Serum-sickness

 Hours to days IgG, IgM, leucocytes
Type IV:
Delayed hypersensitivity

1. Tuberculin

2. Contact dermatitis

 Hours to days T cells, lymphokines, macrophages.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.
